Today, Linea and Ethereum Mainnet upgrade simultaneously for the first time.

This proves zkEVMs can keep pace with Ethereum's upgrade cadence, something many thought impossible.

Learn more:
https://paragraph.com/@linea/ethereum-evolves-and-so-does-linea-introducing-the-fusaka-upgrade
Our evolution:
- zkEVM to London: 4 years
- London to Prague: 4 months
- Prague to Osaka: real-time
Most zkVM teams use RISC-V, running an Ethereum client inside a virtual machine.

It's easier for upgrades, but we believe it sacrifices efficiency.

We develop ZK proofs directly for the EVM. More manual work, but superior performance.
Our long-term strategy will allow us to shift to zkASM and implement any ZK circuits much faster. It's how we onboard new EVM features faster than ever.
For developers: when Ethereum upgrades, you get the newest EVM features immediately. No delays, no compromises.

Deploy the latest Solidity codebases without modification. True EVM equivalence, delivered on time.
But this goes beyond keeping pace.

These changes enhance onboarding, security, and overall performance on Linea.

üö® ETH: Standing on the Edge of a Cliff
I wanted to show you a major long-term chart for Ethereum because we are sitting at the most important price level in years. This isn't just a daily wobble‚Äîit's the whole macro picture.
The $2,800-$3,000 "Zone of Destiny"
Look at that big, gray shaded box on the chart. That's the $2,800 to $3,000 area.
‚Ä¢ This zone is historic. Every time ETH has been here, it has been a fight. It's acted as both a floor (support) that stopped crashes and a ceiling (resistance) that stopped rallies. It's a key pivot point for the entire market cycle.
‚Ä¢ Where are we right now? We are literally testing the bottom edge of that major zone. The chart shows the price sitting right around $2,900-ish (the current live price is actually closer to $3,200 right now, which is a good sign that the chart's support is holding!).
The Big Idea: The "W" Pattern
This whole massive structure that looks like a giant "W" is a classic technical pattern. It suggests two possibilities:
1. THE BULL CASE (The Launchpad ): If we hold this gray zone and bounce strongly (which the live price is suggesting is already happening!), it validates the entire "W" pattern. This pattern implies that the market has finally found its long-term footing. The projected target on this chart is absolutely massive‚Äîup towards $5,900! That would be a huge run and confirm a new leg of the bull market.
2. THE BEAR CASE (The Cliff ): If the price breaks down decisively below $2,800‚ÄîI'm talking about closing and staying below it‚Äîthen this beautiful pattern is ruined. It tells us the selling pressure is too strong, and we would likely be heading back toward the previous deep low, which is around the $1,475 mark.

Even as they processed 85% of all Ethereum transactions, the ETH burn from their activity was nearly zero. That ends TODAY.  Fusaka (combining Osaka + Fulu + PeerDAS) finally solves Ethereum‚Äôs biggest economic flaw: aligning value with growth.  ‚ú® Here‚Äôs What Actually Changes: ‚úÖ 1. Real Fees from Every L2 Transaction EIP-7918 ensures L2s pay meaningful fees to Ethereum ‚Äî meaning every L2 transaction now directly contributes to ETH burn. This is the most significant value shift since EIP-1559.  ‚úÖ 2. A New Burn Engine Powered by L2s Previously, ETH burn came mostly from mainnet activity. Now, every L2 blob has a minimum cost that is burned. More L2 adoption = more ETH burned = ETH becomes structurally scarcer.  ‚úÖ 3. The Return to Deflation Pre-Fusaka: ~620k ETH issued vs. ~350k burned = inflation. Post-Fusaka: L2 burn adds 200k‚Äì400k+ ETH/year. ‚Üí Combined burn could reach 600k‚Äì1.2M ETH/year, flipping ETH back to deflationary.  ‚úÖ 4. PeerDAS Fuels the Flywheel By reducing data bandwidth by 85%, L2s can publish more blobs cheaply ‚Üí more transactions, more fees, more ETH burned. Growth directly drives scarcity.  ‚úÖ 5. Mainnet Gets a Boost Too Block gas limit increases from 36M ‚Üí 60M = more transactions per block = higher base fee burn on L1.  ‚úÖ 6. Lower Fees ‚Üí More Activity ‚Üí More Burn Cheaper swaps, bridges, gaming, and social apps on L2s will drive adoption ‚Äî creating a self-reinforcing cycle of usage and burn.  üß†Why This Matters: Ethereum is no longer just scaling ‚Äî it‚Äôs monetizing its own scaling. Pre-Fusaka: L2 growth = less ETH burned. Post-Fusaka: L2 growth = more ETH burned.     #Ethereum  #Fusaka  #ETH  $ETH

Introducing AgentFlux: a privacy-preserving AI framework for onchain finance.

Developed by @interop_labs,  AgentFlux enables agentic automation without sending sensitive information to the cloud. üßµ üëá 
Investors and firms of all sizes face a challenge deploying AI In finance: The best AI agents run in the cloud.

Using cloud-based AI requires uploading strategies and sensitive client data.

Using AI agents onchain requires uploading private keys üö®
AgentFlux provides a new architecture. Sensitive reasoning and tool selection run locally, while heavier, non-sensitive compute can be delegated.

Keys, prompts and trading context remain under local control.
"You never want to get public cloud models to be as good as doing your strategy as you are," Axelar co-founder @sergey_nog said in an interview with @CoinDesk, which covered the AgentFlux launch (https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2025/12/04/axelar-unveils-agentflux-to-bring-ai-agents-onchain-without-cloud-risks).
The framework was incubated at @interop_labs, developers of Axelar, with collaborators from @UW. It is being released as open-source software for developers and institutional teams.
A demo app shows the model executing an end-to-end onchain trading workflow using a Coinbase tool-calling environment on Ethereum. It handles planning, tool selection and transaction steps without exposing keys or client data.
AgentFlux separates each tool call into two subtasks: selecting the correct function and generating structured arguments. Fine-tuned adapters improve local model accuracy and reliability in multi-step trading flows.

Read a more complete description in Axelar's blog announcing AgentFlux:
https://t.co/8kK5jikfNB
For institutions, this restores a familiar pattern: keys stay local, transactions are constructed in controlled environments and only the required outputs leave the perimeter. AgentFlux aligns AI workflows with existing risk and compliance expectations.
AgentFlux is open-source and designed for extension across trading, portfolio analytics, reporting, treasury operations and other sensitive financial workloads.
Explore AgentFlux:
Landing page: http://agent-flux.github.io/
Research paper: http://arxiv.org/abs/2510.00229
GitHub repository and trading demo: http://github.com/efeslab/AgentFlux

Staking was long blocked by SEC rules, but the dam just broke: Grayscale now stakes >70% of its $4.7B ETH ETF holdings, and BlackRock filed for its own staked ETH ETF.

With $18B in assets, ETH ETFs already control almost as much staked ETH as Lido ‚Äî and that‚Äôs before the real inflows hit.

Here‚Äôs who wins (and loses) in the coming staking wars.üëá

~~ Analysis by @JackInabinet ~~

Winner-Take-All Markets

Two core dynamics in crypto staking naturally push the system toward winner-take-all outcomes, where a single provider can end up dominating the market.

Liquidity Advantages:

The largest staking provider for a given crypto asset can offer its stakers superior liquidity, a top concern for many price-sensitive institutional holders, including ETF managers who must process redemptions.

For example, staking with Lido, which controls 24% of all ETH staked, yields stETH, a fungible deposit receipt that can be swapped instantly at market prices or redeemed over a period of days at a 1:1 ratio for ETH. Whether swapping or redeeming, stETH holders typically receive stronger execution than alternatives thanks to its deeper liquidity and larger validator base.

Economies of Scale:

Currently, Lido takes a 10% commission on customers' ETH staking rewards, a lower fee than any other blue-chip staking provider.

Although Lido has never reduced commissions as part of a low-cost strategy, a top staking provider could readily pull in more stakers by cutting fees, underpricing rivals while boosting profits as users chase superior rewards.

Clear examples of this dynamic exist in TradFi, where Vanguard cemented its pioneering reputation in the 1980s by introducing low-cost passive indexing. Those products offered better returns than the high-fee active strategies that prevailed then. Today the asset-management landscape is ruled by low-cost passive indexers, with an unmistakable link between lower fees and larger assets under management.

Who Wins?

While Lido is the current standout Ethereum staking provider, as an increasing number of staked ETH ETFs come to market, it is possible the current order is upended.

Coinbase is still well behind the leading ETH staking providers, controlling just one quarter of Lido's share at 6.3% of total ETH staked, but it remains the clear heavyweight in institutional crypto custody. As of June, Coinbase custodied 81% of all U.S. ETF crypto asset holdings.

Although it might be logical to assume that Lido will simply expand its staking dominance with ETF managers incentivized to use Lido for its liquidity advantages and economies of scale, Coinbase is arguably better positioned to capture these flows.

In traditional finance, relationships matter. ETF managers need a custodial staking partner with a name and face they can trust to withstand regulatory scrutiny, provide audited assurances, and (in a worst case scenario) be summoned to court.

Coinbase spent years cultivating relationships across Wall Street, and successfully embedded itself as the default crypto custodian for institutions in the process. So when those same institutions look for a staking partner, Coinbase may be the natural first call.

Concentration Dangers

If BlackRock, which manages the largest ETH ETF, were to stake its ETH through Coinbase, a firm in which BlackRock's products hold 7% ownership, the exchange could quickly overtake Lido as the dominant ETH staking provider.

When Coinbase staking products receive inflows from ETFs, the amount of liquidity available for redemptions naturally increases. Additionally, Coinbase can solidify its control over staking markets by dropping staking commissions, providing a financial incentive for even more stakers to make the switch.

In Ethereum and many other Proof of Stake blockchains, there are three critical staking dominance thresholds. As a staking group crosses each one, it gains greater influence over the chain and access to higher staking rewards. In turn, these higher yields help to reinforce the leader's position, discouraging delegation elsewhere and accelerating centralization.

These systemic centralization risks will exist regardless of which operator becomes dominant, but if Coinbase surpassed these thresholds, the outcome would be especially stark, effectively handing total authority over a blockchain designed for decentralization to a centralized corporation accountable only to its shareholders.
